thread.title: Durham's 'Dipper Man' shortlisted for 2018 British Farming Awards

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Durham's 'Dipper Man' shortlisted for 2018 British Farming Awards
text:
Durham's 'Dipper Man' shortlisted for 2018 British Farming Awards Neil Fell's sheep dipping business has been nominated for the Contractor of the Year award Share Neil Fell runs a mobile sheep dipping business in Durham (Image: Neil Fell) Get business updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! The finalists for the 2018 British Farming Awards have been announced, and a North East sheep dipping firm has made it to the shortlist.
Neil Fell’s sheep dipping company, NR Fell Mobile Sheep Dipping, has been nominated for an award.
The Durham businessman - who is known as the “Dipper Man” on Twitter - has been trading for six years.
His business is the only one from the North East to be nominated for an award.
The business is in the running to be named Contractor of the Year.
Commenting on his nomination Mr Fell said: “Being nominated means that I have been recognised for what I have been doing in the field. It’s nice to be recognised and it’s a really nice accolade.
“We are trying to promote the job that I do for farmers and I am looking to expand the business a bit more.” Neil Fell runs a mobile sheep dipping business in Durham (Image: Neil Fell)
Mr Fell has been nominated for his use of an innovative new piece of mobile machinery, which is used during the sheep dipping process.
A total of 60 finalists have been named across 15 categories at the awards, which recognise the hard work, innovation and determination of the British farming industry.
The categories cover farming’s core sectors, including arable, beef, sheep, dairy and machinery. Read More Confidence among North East farmers set to plummet on Brexit
Now in its sixth year, the British Farming Awards event is organised by AgriBriefing - the parent company of Farmers Guardian, Arable Farming, and Dairy Farmer.
Two of the awards will be announced exclusively during the ceremony, which is taking place at the National Conference Centre, in Birmingham, on Thursday, October 18.
Farmers Guardian Editor Ben Briggs says: “The British Farming Awards celebrate and showcase the innovation, enthusiasm and drive of individuals who make UK agriculture so special.
“Farmers feed the nation, shape our stunning countryside and are the heartbeat of rural communities, which is why it is so important we recognise their contribution through these awards.”
Andrew Thornber, Morrisons manufacturing managing director, says: “We are pleased to be sponsoring the British Farming Awards in 2018 following the success of last year’s event.
“We are proud to work with and buy from British farmers. Read More Billionaire brothers reveal multimillion-pound plans for Newcastle Racecourse
“In fact, we work directly with more than 3,000 livestock farmers, over 200 growers and - with the acquisition of Chippendale Foods - we now work directly with 40 egg producers as well. We prefer to deal directly with farmers because we believe this works best for both parties.
“We remain committed to developing strong and enduring relationships with British farmers, helping us to understand better and work together to build long-term sustainability.” Like us on Facebook
